review.title: Taming Numbers and Durations in the Model Checking Integrated Planning System
review.abstract: The Model Checking Integrated Planning System (MIPS) is a temporal least commitment heuristic search planner based on a flexible object-oriented workbench architecture. Its design clearly separates explicit and symbolic directed exploration algorithms from the set of on-line and off-line computed estimates and associated data structures. MIPS has shown distinguished performance in the last two international planning competitions. In the last event the description language was extended from pure propositional planning to include numerical state variables, action durations, and plan quality objective functions. Plans were no longer sequences of actions but time-stamped schedules. As a participant of the fully automated track of the competition, MIPS has proven to be a general system; in each track and every benchmark domain it efficiently computed plans of remarkable quality. This article introduces and analyzes the most important algorithmic novelties that were necessary to tackle the new layers of expressiveness in the benchmark problems and to achieve a high level of performance. The extensions include critical path analysis of sequentially generated plans to generate corresponding optimal parallel plans. The linear time algorithm to compute the parallel plan bypasses known NP hardness results for partial ordering by scheduling plans with respect to the set of actions and the imposed precedence relations. The efficiency of this algorithm also allows us to improve the exploration guidance: for each encountered planning state the corresponding approximate sequential plan is scheduled. One major strength of MIPS is its static analysis phase that grounds and simplifies parameterized predicates, functions and operators, that infers knowledge to minimize the state description length, and that detects domain object symmetries. The latter aspect is analyzed in detail. MIPS has been developed to serve as a complete and optimal state space planner, with admissible estimates, exploration engines and branching cuts. In the competition version, however, certain performance compromises had to be made, including floating point arithmetic, weighted heuristic search exploration according to an inadmissible estimate and parameterized optimization.

metadata.title: Taming Numbers and Durations in the Model Checking Integrated Planning System

sections.text: MIPS has performed excellently in the last two international planning competitions. In the latter case, the descriptive language has been expanded from mere proposal planning to numerical state variables, action duration and plan quality objective functions. Plans were no longer sequences of action, but timed schedules. As a participant in fully automated competition planning, MIPS has proven to be a general system, efficiently calculating plans of remarkable quality in each track and in each benchmark area. This article presents and analyzes the most important algorithmic innovations needed to address the new levels of expressivity in benchmark problems and achieve a high level of performance. Enhancements include a critical path analysis of sequentially generated plans to generate corresponding optimal parallel plans. The linear time algorithm for calculating the parallel plan circumvents known NP hardness results for the partial arrangement of planning plans in terms of the set of measures and pre-conditional relationships.

sections.heading: 3. Architecture of MIPS
sections.text: Figure 1 shows the main components of MIPS and the data flow from the input definition of the domain and the problem instance to the resulting schedule in the output. As shaded in light grey, MIPS is divided into four parts: pre-compilation, heuristics, search algorithms and post-compilation (scheduling). Henceforth, the planning process is roughly grouped into three phases, pre-compilation, heuristic search planning and the construction of schedules. The problem and domain description files are fed into the system, analysed and grounded, which fixes the state space problem to be solved. The interim result is implicit, but can be stored in a file for use by other planners and model checkers. The basics of the pre-compilation are described in Section 3.2.The next step defines the planning process.

sections.heading: 3.1 Example Problem
sections.text: The running example of the paper is an example of a fairly simple PDDL2.1 problem in Zeno-Travel. It is illustrated in Figure 2. The initial configuration is shown to the left of the figure and the destination configuration to the right of it. Some global and local numerical variable mappings are not shown. Figures 3 and 4 provide the domain and problem specifications 1. The instance requires a time schedule to fly passengers (dan, scott and ernie) anywhere on a small map (including cities city-a, city-b, city-c and city-d) to their respective destinations by airplane (plane). Boarding and disembarking takes a constant time. The airplane has a fixed fuel capacity. Fuel and time are consumed according to the distances between cities and cruising speed. Fuel can be restored by refueling the airplane.

sections.heading: 3.2 Precompiler
sections.text: In fact, most of them are able to play by the rules they have imposed on themselves.

sections.heading: 3.3 Heuristics
sections.text: MIPS contains the following heuristic estimates. Relaxed Planning Euristics (RPH) The approximation of the number of planning steps required to solve the planning problem, removing all deletion effects (Hoffmann & Nebel, 2001). Heuristics is constructive, i.e. it returns the number of operators that appear in relaxed planning. Numerical Relaxed Planning Euristics (Numerical RPH) Our extension to RPH for dealing with numbers is a combined propository and numerical approximation scheme that allows the application of multiple operators.Sample database heuristic (explicitly PDB) Various planning space abstractions are found greedily and result in a selection of pattern databases that fit into the main memory. Unlike RPH, the pattern database can be designed to dissolve, which is required for optimal planning in A * (Edelkamp, 2001c) symbolic DPH search engine symbolic (symbolic DPH) functionality.

sections.heading: 3.4 Exploration Algorithms
sections.text: The algorithm portfolio comprises three explicit heuristic search algorithms, the A * algorithm (Hart, Nilsson, & Raphael, 1968) being a variant of Dijkstra's singlesource short path exploration scheme executed on the basis of a reweighted state space graph. Subordinate heuristics can be shown to generate optimal plans (Pearl, 1985). Weighting the influence of heuristic estimation can accelerate solution finding, but also influence optimality (Pohl, 1977).Iterative-Deepening A * (IDA *) The memory-limited variant of A * is suitable for large exploration problems with valuation functions of small integer ranges and low time complexity (Korf, 1985).IDA * can be expanded with bit-state hashing (Edelkamp & Meyer, 2001) to improve double detection of ordinary transit stable tables (Hoffmann, 1994).Reinforced search problem (D).

sections.heading: 3.5 Composition of the Competition Version
sections.text: In Figure 1, we shaded the parts that were actually used in the competitive version of MIPS in dark gray. We used relaxed planning heuristically for sequential plan generation. We used relaxed planning heuristically while it was used in temporary domains. Only in Level 2, we used the numerically advanced RPH techniques since it was added to the system in the final weeks of the competition. We experimented with (symbolic) pattern databases with different results. As pattern databases are purely propositional in our implementation and do not offer the restoration of operators in the optimal abstract plan, we did not include them in the competitive version. Our approach to enhance relaxed planning with numerical information helps find plans in challenging numerical domains such as settlers and was influenced by Hoffmann's work on his competing planner Metric-FF (Hoffmann, 2002a).

sections.heading: 3.6 Visualization
sections.text: For the visualization of plans with MIPS, we have expanded the animation system Vega (Hipke, 2000); a client-server architecture that executes a commented algorithm on the server side, which is visualized on the client side in a Java front end. The main purpose of the server is to make algorithms accessible via TCP / IP. It is able to receive commands from several clients at the same time. We have expanded Vega in two ways (see Figures 7 and 8).Called Chart Visualization Gannt Charts are representations for schedules in which horizontal bars are drawn for each activity, indicating the estimated duration / cost. The user selects any planner to be executed and the domain and problem files, which are interpreted as command line options. Alternatively, established plans can be sent directly to the visualizer with a void planner.

sections.heading: 4.1 Temporal Model
sections.text: The simplest approach to solving a time planning problem is to generate a sequential plan. Of course, this option assumes that the time structure only contributes to the value of the plan and not to its accuracy. That is, it assumes that there is in fact no necessary simultaneity in a valid plan. In cases where measures are achieved at their starting points and these are deleted at their end points, contemporaneity can be a necessary part of the structure of a valid plan. Definition 5 (Sequential Plan) A solution to a planning problem P = < S, I, O > in the form of a sequential plan is an ordered sequence of operators.

sections.heading: 4.3 Critical Path Analysis
sections.text: A critical path is a sequence of activities, so the total time for activities on that path is greater than or equal to any other path of the operators. A delay in any tasks on the critical path results in a delay in the project. At the heart of PERT is a network of tasks required to complete a project that shows the order in which the tasks must be completed and the dependencies between them. As shown in Figure 10, PERT scheduling reduces to a variant of Dijkstra's shortest path algorithm in acyclic graphs (Cormen, Leiserson, & Rivest, 1990). As a fact, the algorithm provides the length of the critical path, not the plan derived from it. However, observing the temporary plan is simple. In the algorithms, e (Oi) is the most temporary end time of the operator Oi, i.

sections.heading: 4.4 On the Optimality of MIPS
sections.text: Since MIPS optimally plans the sequence plans, the question remains whether the system will ultimately find an optimal plan. However, in the competition, the system ends when the first sequence plan is found. As relaxed planning is heuristically not permitted, all A * variants cannot guarantee optimal (sequential or parallel) planning. However, it is desirable to calculate optimal plans, even if - due to limited computing resources - the search for optimal but limited plans is difficult. This leads directly to the following naïve plan renumeration algorithms: Each operator starts or ends either at the beginning or end of another operator's time. Therefore, at least a limited number of measures in the optimal plan require a potentially exponential but limited number of possible parallel plans.

sections.text: Acceleration techniques such as the detection of duplicates in sequential planning must be carefully selected to maintain the parallel plan length optimization, as the following example shows. sections.heading: 4.6 Heuristic Search
sections.text: Heuristic search algorithms such as A * and IDA * reorder the traversing of states and (assuming no state caching is required) do not compromise the completeness and optimality of the always available wrapper. The efficiency of the wrapper depends directly on the quality of the itinerary enumeration. In the competitive version of MIPS, we did not use any time packaging because no optimal solutions were required and the practical runtime behavior is poor. Instead, we used an A * search engine that ends with the first established solution. The question remains: Is there still hope of finding near-optimal parallel maps? A general result that is also applicable to infinite graphics (Pearl, 1985): If the cost of each infinite path is unlimited, A * s cost function f = g + h will maintain the optimality of the state plan.

sections.heading: 4.7 Arbitrary Plan Objectives
sections.text: In Figure 13, we present two plans found by MIPS for the objective functions of minimizing total fuel consumption and minimizing the connection (+ (* 10 (total time)) (* 1 (total fuel consumption)). In the first case, we calculated an optimal value of 1,333.33, while in the second case, we set 7,666.67 as the optimized value. In optimizing time, the sequence of boarding and zooming actions is important. In optimizing total fuel consumption, we reduce the speed to reduce fuel consumption to 333.33 per flight, but we can take the first passenger on board immediately. We also save two refueling actions with respect to the first case. In increasing the importance of time, we can swap refueling actions for time, so that both zoom and flight actions are selected for the complex sequence value.

sections.heading: 5. Object Symmetries
sections.text: An important feature of parameterized predicates, functions and action descriptions in the domain specification file is that actions for different parameter bindings on objects are transparent. Unique information is only present in the problem instance file. In the case of typed domains, symmetry is considered a permutation of objects present in the current state, in the target representation and transparent to the group of operators. There are n!, n = | OBJ |, possible permutations of the set of objects. Taking into account all type information, the number of possible permutations is reduced to (nt1, t2,., tk) = n! t1! t2!. − tk! − where ti is the number of objects with type i, i · for these planes, we have the number of possible permutations to (nt1, t2, tk) = n!

sections.text: In this section, we compute the subset of SYMM, which includes all object pairs, for which the entire planning problem is symmetrical. sections.heading: 5.2 Including Goal Symmetry Conditions
sections.text: Symmetries that are present in the initial state can disappear or reappear during exploration in a predictive chain planner such as MIPS. In the DesertRats domain, for example, the initial storage tanks are indistinguishable, so only one of them should be loaded into the truck. As soon as the fuel content of the storage tanks decreases or the tanks are moved to another location, the previously existing symmetries are broken. However, when two tanks are emptied in one place, they can be considered symmetrical again. However, the target conditions do not change over time, only the initial state I changes to the current state C. Therefore, in a pre-compilation phase, we refine the set SYMM to SYMM. "

sections.heading: 5.3 Pruning Operators
sections.text: If a planning problem with the current state C-S is symmetrical with respect to the operator, the problem with the branching factor is significantly lower. Lemma 4 indicates how symmetry is used to reduce exploration. Lemma 4 If operator O is applicable in S and S = S = S ² o ² is applicable, then in S andO (S) [o ² o ² is applicable.

sections.heading: 6. Related Work
sections.text: STRIPS problems have been addressed using various planning techniques, notably SAT planning (Kautz & Selman, 1996), IP planning (Kautz & Walser, 1999), CSPplanung (Rintanen & Jungholt, 1999), graph relaxation (Blum & Furst, 1995) and heuristic search planning (Bonet & Geffner, 2001).Solving planning problems with numerical prerequisites and effects as permitted in Level 2 and Level 3 problems is generally indecisive (Helmert, 2002).

sections.heading: 6.1 Temporal Planning Approaches
sections.text: This year, it is as far as ever in the history of the city, where it is as far as never before in the history of the city.

sections.heading: 6.2 Symmetry Detection in Planning and Model Checkers
sections.text: Most previous results in symmetry reduction in planning, e.g. (Gue "re" and "Alami," 2001), neglect the combinatorial explosion of possible symmetries or at least assume that the information about existing symmetries in the domain is provided by users. In contrast, we share similarities with the approach of Fox & Long (1999,2002) by fully automating the symmetry plane in the form of an object transposition matrix. Our work is based on similarities produced by the TIM inference module (Fox & Long, 1998). While searching for additional information at the current symmetry level in the form of an object transformation, the matrix is stored and updated with each state. Our approach is different in the sense that it efficiently calculates object symmetries for each state and it does not consume additional space per node expansion. Model verification has a long tradition of symmetry in 1999 (Clarke).

sections.heading: 6.3 Model Checking Planners
sections.text: In 2000, two other symbolic planners participated: PropPlan (Fourman, 2000) and BDDPlan (Ho � lldobler & Sto � r, 2000). Although they have not received any awards for performance, they show interesting characteristics. ProbPlan introduces symbolic forward and predictive techniques to explore propositional planning problems with prerequisites for generalized action conditions and generalized action effects. BDD-Plan is based on solving the entailment problem in the full ADL Miconic-10 Elevator Domain (Koehler, 2000). BDD-Plan is based on solving the entailment problem in flowing calculation with BDDs. At the time, the authors acknowledged that precise domain encoding and symbolic heuristic search in MIPS were improvements.In the model-based planner MBP, the paradigm of planning as symbolic model verification (Giunchiglia, 1999) was implemented.

sections.heading: 7. Conclusions
sections.text: With the competition planning system MIPS we have a flexible system for a heuristic approach, explicit and symbolic search planners who find plans in finitebranche numerical problems. Planners analyze, precompile, solve and plan problem cases, including complex with duration, resource variables and various objective functions. The main contributions of planners are that the object-oriented workbench architecture to select and combine, different search algorithms and storage structures. The design includes efficient fact-finding to distinguish the constant from the fluctuations, bundle the facts into groups, and that the infantry produces static object-symmetry symmetries.

sections.heading: Acknowledgments
sections.text: The author would like to thank Derek Long and Maria Fox for the helpful discussions on this work and Malte Helmert for his participation in the second planning competition. The list of comments by the editors and anonymous reviewers has contributed significantly to the text improvement. The work is supported by the Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft (DFG, German Research Foundation) in the projects Heuristic Search (eds. 74 / 3) and Directed Model Checking (eds. 74 / 2).

referenceMentions.context: Additional synergies are exploited in the automated compilation of protocol software model checking problems into planner inputs (Edelkamp, 2003).

In symbolic model checking (McMillan, 1993; Clarke, McMillan, Dill, & Hwang, 1992), (fixed-length) binary encodings of system states are used, so that each state can be represented by its characteristic function representation.
The unique symbolic representation of sets of states as Boolean formulae through binary decision diagrams (BDDs) (Bryant, 1992) is often much smaller than the explicit one.
Moreover, it combines symbolic and explicit search planning in the form of symbolic pattern databases (Edelkamp, 2002b).

The planner MIPS implements heuristic search algorithms like A* (Pearl, 1985) and IDA* (Korf, 1985) for exploration, which include state-to-goal approximation into the search process to rank the states to be expanded next.

The planner MIPS implements heuristic search algorithms like A* (Pearl, 1985) and IDA* (Korf, 1985) for exploration, which include state-to-goal approximation into the search process to rank the states to be expanded next.

Heuristic search has brought considerable gains to both planning (Bonet & Geffner, 2001; Refanidis & Vlahavas, 2000; Hoffmann & Nebel, 2001; Bertoli, Cimatti, & Roveri, 2001a; Jensen, Bryant, & Veloso, 2002; Feng & Hansen, 2002) and model checking (Yang & Dill, 1998; Edelkamp et al., 2003; Groce & Visser, 2002; Bloem, Ravi, & Somenzi, 2000; Ruys, 2003).

Heuristic search has brought considerable gains to both planning (Bonet & Geffner, 2001; Refanidis & Vlahavas, 2000; Hoffmann & Nebel, 2001; Bertoli, Cimatti, & Roveri, 2001a; Jensen, Bryant, & Veloso, 2002; Feng & Hansen, 2002) and model checking (Yang & Dill, 1998; Edelkamp et al., 2003; Groce & Visser, 2002; Bloem, Ravi, & Somenzi, 2000; Ruys, 2003).
The competition version of MIPS refers to initial work (Edelkamp & Reffel, 1999a) in heuristic symbolic exploration of planning domains with the μcke model checker (Biere, 1997).
As confirmed by other attempts (Weismüller, 1998), who started experimenting with PDDL specification in μcke, state minimization is in fact crucial.

In the second international planning competition MIPS (Edelkamp & Helmert, 2001) could handle the STRIPS (Fikes & Nilsson, 1971) subset of the PDDL language (McDermott, 2000) and some additional features from ADL (Pednault, 1989), namely negative preconditions and (universal) conditional effects.

In the second international planning competition MIPS (Edelkamp & Helmert, 2001) could handle the STRIPS (Fikes & Nilsson, 1971) subset of the PDDL language (McDermott, 2000) and some additional features from ADL (Pednault, 1989), namely negative preconditions and (universal) conditional effects.

The competition version of MIPS refers to initial work (Edelkamp & Reffel, 1999a) in heuristic symbolic exploration of planning domains with the μcke model checker (Biere, 1997). This approach was effective in sample puzzle solving (Edelkamp & Reffel, 1998) and in hardware verification problems (Reffel & Edelkamp, 1999). For implementing a propositional planner, we first used our own BDD library called StaticBdd, in which large node tables are allocated prior to their use. During the implementation process we changed the BDD representation mainly to improve performance for small planning problems. We selected the public domain c++ BDD package Buddy (LindNielsen, 1999), which is more flexible. The planning process was semi-automated (Edelkamp & Reffel, 1999b); variable encodings were provided by hand, while the representations of all operators were established by enumerating all possible parameter instances. Once the state space encoding and action transition relation were fixed, exploration in the form of a symbolic breadth-first search of the state-space could be executed. At that time, we were not aware of any other work in BDD-based planning such as the work of Cimatti et al. (1997), which is likely the first link to planning via symbolic model checking.
In between the planning competitions, explicit (Edelkamp, 2001c) and symbolic pattern databases (Edelkamp, 2002b) were proposed as off-line estimators for completely explored problem abstractions.
In between the planning competitions, explicit (Edelkamp, 2001c) and symbolic pattern databases (Edelkamp, 2002b) were proposed as off-line estimators for completely explored problem abstractions.
1 problems are presented in (Edelkamp, 2001b).

This work was extended in (Edelkamp, 2002a), where we presented two approximate exploration techniques to bound and to fix numerical domains, first results on symmetry detection based on fact groups, critical path scheduling, an any-time wrapper to produce optimal plans, and a numerical extension to RPH.

The planning system was developed in the spirit of the heuristic search framework, HSF for short (Edelkamp, 1999), which allows attachment of newly implemented problem (puzzle) domains to an already compiled system.
In contrast to RPH, pattern database can be designed to be disjoint yielding an admissible estimate as needed for optimal planning in A* (Edelkamp, 2001c).
Symbolic pattern database heuristic (symbolic PDB) Symbolic PDBs apply to explicit and symbolic heuristic search engines (Edelkamp, 2002b).
For lower bound heuristics, A* can be shown to generate optimal plans (Pearl, 1985).
Weighting the influence of the heuristic estimate may accelerate solution finding, but also affects optimality (Pohl, 1977).
Iterative-Deepening A* (IDA*) The memory-limited variant of A* is suited to large exploration problems with evaluation functions of small integer range and low time complexity (Korf, 1985).
Enforced HC searches with an improved evaluation in a breadth-first manner and commits established action selections as final (Hoffmann, 2000).

Our approach to extend the relaxed planning heuristic with numerical information helps to find plans in challenging numerical domains like Settlers and was influenced by Hoffmann’s work on his competing planner Metric-FF (Hoffmann, 2002a).

A Dial priority queue (Dial, 1969) has linear run time behavior, if the maximal value w(u, v) + h(v) − h(u) of all edges (u, v) in the weighted state space graph (labelled with heuristic h) is bounded by a constant.
In (Edelkamp, 2002a) we experimented with an enumeration approach to fix numerical variables to a finite domain, and with an any-time wrapper for optimization of objective functions.

For visualization of plans with MIPS we extended the animation system Vega (Hipke, 2000); a Client-Server architecture that runs an annotated algorithm on the server side, which is visualized on the client side in a Java frontend.
A less restrictive notion of independence, in which several actions may occur at the same time even if one deletes an add-effect of another is provided in (Knoblock, 1994).
For optimizing plans (Bäckström, 1998) defines parallel execution time as max{ti + d(Oi) | Oi ∈ {O1, .
In order to find optimal schedules of sequential plans an approach similar to (Bäckström, 1998) would be necessary.
Many algorithms have been suggested to convert sequential plans into partially ordered ones (Pednault, 1986; Regnier & Fade, 1991; Veloso, Pérez, & Carbonell, 1990).

However, the problem of minimum constraint “deordering” has also been proven to be NP-hard, unless the so-called validity check is polynomial (Bäckström, 1998), where deordering maintains validity of the plan by lessening its constrainedness, i.
Enumeration schemes do not contradict known undecidability results in numerical planning (Helmert, 2002).
The question remains: is there still hope of finding near optimal parallel plans? A general result also applicable for infinite graphs was established by (Pearl, 1985): If the cost of every
Solving planning problems with numerical preconditions and effects as allowed in Level 2 and Level 3 problems is undecidable in general (Helmert, 2002).
The system Metric-FF (Hoffmann, 2002a) extends FF (Hoffmann & Nebel, 2001) as a forward chaining heuristic state space planner for Level 2 problems.
HSTS (Muscettola, 1994) is a constraint-based planning system based on temporal activity networks, written in LISP and CRL.
Some subclasses of infinite branching problems like timed automata exhibit a finite partitioning through a symbolic representation of states (Pettersson, 1999).
implemented this temporal network structure, since this is the main data structure when exploring timed automata as done by the model checker Uppaal (Pettersson, 1999).

Model checking research has a long tradition in symmetry reduction (Clarke et al., 1999). In recent work, Rintanen (2003) connects symmetry detection in planning to model checking approaches for transition systems and SAT solving.
In the 2000 competition, two other symbolic planners took part: PropPlan (Fourman, 2000), and BDDPlan (Hölldobler & Stör, 2000).
It performed well in the full ADL Miconic-10 elevator domain (Koehler, 2000).

In the Model-Based Planner MBP the paradigm of planning as symbolic model checking (Giunchiglia & Traverso, 1999) has been implemented for non-deterministic planning domains (Cimatti et al., 1998), which can be classified into weak, strong, and strong-cyclic planning, with plans that are represented as state-action tables.
With SetA*, (Jensen et al., 2002) provide an improved imple-
mentation of the symbolic heuristic search algorithm BDDA* (Edelkamp & Reffel, 1998) and Weighted BDDA* (Edelkamp, 2001a).
As above, the planning benchmarks considered are seemingly simple for single-state heuristic search exploration (Hoffmann, 2002b; Helmert, 2001).

metadata.abstractText: The Model Checking Integrated Planning System (MIPS) is a temporal least commitment heuristic search planner based on a flexible object-oriented workbench architecture. Its design clearly separates explicit and symbolic directed exploration algorithms from the set of on-line and off-line computed estimates and associated data structures. MIPS has shown distinguished performance in the last two international planning competitions. In the last event the description language was extended from pure propositional planning to include numerical state variables, action durations, and plan quality objective functions. Plans were no longer sequences of actions but time-stamped schedules. As a participant of the fully automated track of the competition, MIPS has proven to be a general system; in each track and every benchmark domain it efficiently computed plans of remarkable quality. This article introduces and analyzes the most important algorithmic novelties that were necessary to tackle the new layers of expressiveness in the benchmark problems and to achieve a high level of performance. The extensions include critical path analysis of sequentially generated plans to generate corresponding optimal parallel plans. The linear time algorithm to compute the parallel plan bypasses known NP hardness results for partial ordering by scheduling plans with respect to the set of actions and the imposed precedence relations. The efficiency of this algorithm also allows us to improve the exploration guidance: for each encountered planning state the corresponding approximate sequential plan is scheduled. One major strength of MIPS is its static analysis phase that grounds and simplifies parameterized predicates, functions and operators, that infers knowledge to minimize the state description length, and that detects domain object symmetries. The latter aspect is analyzed in detail. MIPS has been developed to serve as a complete and optimal state space planner, with admissible estimates, exploration engines and branching cuts. In the competition version, however, certain performance compromises had to be made, including floating point arithmetic, weighted heuristic search exploration according to an inadmissible estimate and parameterized optimization.
